Vitalina has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about US$145). SPBD loans are Vitalina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Education and home improvement, and also her church activities are important to her. Even though she's the one who is applying for the loan, really her husband did all the hard work to make sure the buisness will succcessful.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, back sprayer, bush knives, shovel

loans.name: Matalena

texts.en:
Matalena V., 39, is married with 4 children. She has many years' experience in the taro/banana business. She sells to the village community and Fugalei market 3 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD.

Matalena expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (about US$ 125). SPBD loans are Matalena’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Because her balance restarts, she will use all her loan for her project.

The whole family spend their weekends at the plantation maintaining their plantation in good condition but mostly the head of the family is responsible in planning everything for the betterment of her business.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, insect sprayer, bush knife, shovel

loans.name: Talosaga

texts.en:
Talosaga V., 42, is married with 5 children. She has many years' experience in the taro/banana business. She sells to the village community and Fugalei market 3 days per week.

Talosaga has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (about US$ 104). SPBD loans are Talosaga’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

She will spend all this first loan on her business only. Her husband is the main boss of the project; he is the one that does planning for maintaining their plantation.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, insect sprayer, bush knife, shovel

loans.name: Vitalina

texts.en:
Vitalina M., 41, is married with 4 children. She has many years experience in the taro/banana business. She sells to the village community and Fugalei market 3 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (about US$ 145).

SPBD loans are Vitalina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Other amounts of her loan will be used for improving her household expenses also her education expenses. Her husband did the hard and dirty work of her business by planning everything for the betterment of their project which is a plantation.

loans.use: Purchase cromozone chemicals, insect sprayer, bush knife, shovel

loans.name: Hasan Jan

texts.en: A 22-year-old young man, Hasan Jan, son of J. G., lives in the Sorkhrood district of the Ningarhar province. There are 8 persons in his family, and he is responsible for solving their financial problems. He is working as a former on his own land, but he doesn’t have enough income from it. He wants to bring a positive change, but for this purpose he needs  some money. Therefore he applied to AFSG for a loan of 30,000 Afghanis to buy some stock and seeds and improve his product. He definitely seems to be an active man and he hopes he will increase his income through this loan.

loans.use: To buy stock and seeds

loans.name: Suesue

texts.en: Fuefue S., 26, is married and is a mother expecting her first baby next month. She has 1 year of experience in the Canteen business. She sells to the students of their village primary school 3 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 280 Tala (~116 USD).  SPBD loans are Fuefue’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Her husband is employed at a shipping company.

loans.use: Purchase a kerosene stove, a sack of flour, a sack of rice, lamp flaps and chickens

loans.name: Tiresa

texts.en:
Tiresa F., 62, is married with 8 children. She has many years of experience in the shop business. She sells to the general public and villagers 7 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~250 USD).

SPBD loans are Tiresa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Tiresa is a strong active lady running a retail shop in her village. Her husband is helping her run the shop. All her children are married and are staying with them.

loans.use: Restock her shop

loans.name: Sivai

texts.en:
Sivai M., 37, is married with 3 children. She has many years of experience in the taro plantation and pancake business. She sells to the general public and villagers 3 days per week.

Sivai has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~250 USD). SPBD loans are Sivai’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Both she and her husband are unemployed, but are self-employed runnning their business. Their three children are schooling at their village primary school.

loans.use: Part of her loan will be used for purchasing gromoxone, sting, weedkiller and for her pancake business

loans.name: Feiloaiga

texts.en: Feiloaiga P., 64, is widowed with 2 children.  She has many years of experience in the sewing business. She sells to the general public and villagers 3 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Feiloaiga’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Her two grown-up daughters both reside in Australia with their husbands.

loans.use: purchasing materials like timber, paint, brushes, and cement for shower

loans.name: Kerena

texts.en: Kerena L., 35, is married with 3 children.  She is running her own plantation with the support from her husband. She has many years of experience in the Taro Plantation business. She sells to the general public 2 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  SPBD loans are Kerena’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: purchase pesticides

loans.name: Sautaua

texts.en: Sautaua I., 48, is married with 3 children.  She has many years of experience in the sewing business. She sells to the villagers 5 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Sautaua’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Her husband works for Sping Water Company, and her three children are schooling in town.

loans.use: purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Melea

texts.en: Melea P., 23, is single with children.  She has 2 year(s) of experience in the Flea Market business. She sells to the villagers 7 days per week. She has previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~83 USD).  SPBD loans are Melea’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  A single female from a family of 2 brothers and 1 sister.

loans.use: purchase fruits and vegetables from the market, and also seeds to start planting for her business.

loans.name: Petesa

texts.en: Petesa K., 29, is married with 2 children.  She has 5 year(s) of experience in the Sewign and vegetable garden business. She sells to the villagers 3 days per week. She has previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 312 Tala (~130 USD).  SPBD loans are Petesa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  She the wife of a Reverand, with three children, running a sewing business. She also does vegetables to support her weekly repayments

loans.use: purchasing materials, threads, needles, buttons, zippers and seeds.

loans.name: Ni Komang Ayu Sumber

texts.id:
Ni Komang Ayu Sumber and her husband and their 3 children live in their own made simple house. For her 2nd term of loan from Dinari, Komang Ayu expanded her business by having 2 crossing piglets (produced from crossing of local and non local breed) and also 2 local piglets. She spent IDR 1 million (around USD 112) for those 4 piglets. Pig feeding cost her IDR 15 thousand per day (around USD 1.7/ day). She can earn a net profit of USD 112 per 3 month period. This money is used to help the family's economic.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva volunteer.

Untuk pinjaman periode ke dua, Komang Ayu Sumber Astuti mengembangkan usaha ternak babinya dengan memelihara dua ekor babi untuk penggemukan jenis crossing dan dua ekor jenis babi lokal Bali. Dengan modal Rp.1.000.000.- sedang sebagian modal dipergunakan untuk persiapan membeli pakan ternaknya. Komang Ayu Sumber Astiti total memelihara 4 ekor babi. Biaya per hari yang diperlukan untuk pakan adalah Rp.15.000.- Pemeliharaan, pembersihan kandang dan pemberian pakan dilakukan dua kali dalam sehari. Dari hasil usaha ini Komang Ayu mendapatkan keuntungan Rp. 1.000.000.- dalam tiga bulan. Dengan keuntungan yang diperoleh tersebut, Komang Ayu bisa membantu suaminya, I Made Sugita, untuk menghidupi 3 anaknya yang masih sekolah. Mereka tinggal bersama dirumah yang mereka bangun sendiri, walaupun sangat sederhana.

loans.use: To buy pig feed (Membeli pakan ternak)

loans.name: Ni Wayan Kari

texts.id:
Ni Wayan Kari is 54 years old and she has one son, Ari Susanta, who is now 20 years old. Ni Wayan Kari is one of Dinari Foundation's client. At the moment she is on her 2nd term loan from Dinari. She used the loan money to buy 3 piglets that cost her IDR 700 thousand (around USD 79). She farmed those piglets in 2 hut made of bamboo structure. In a 6 month period she can earn IDR 1 million (around USD 112). She even has regular customers already for her pigs. The money she earned is used to help her to improve her family's welfare.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva volunteer.

Wayan Kari adalah salah satu Client binaan Yayasan Dinari. Saat ini adalah pinjaman periode ke dua. Modal pijaman tersebut dipergunakan untk membeli tiga ekor babi dengan harga Rp.700.000.- Ni Wayan Kari memelihara ketiga ekor babinya dalam dua kandang yang hanya terbuat dari bambu sebagai pembatas dindingnya. Sekarang Ni Wayan Kari sudah bisa membeli 3 ekor babi untuk penggemukan. Ni Wayan Kari berumur 54 tahun dan memiliki satu orang anak bernama Ari Susanta yang berumur 20 tahun. Rumah yang ditempati sekarang adalah jerih payah mereka berdua. Dalam 6 bulan Ni Wayan Kari meraup keuntungan sebesar Rp. 1.000.000.- Ni Wayan Kari tidak perlu khawatir dengan pemasaran babinya, karena sudah ada langganan yang membeli babinya. Keuntungan ini digunakan untuk tambahan keperluan rumah tangganya.

loans.use: To buy piglet (Membeli bibit babi)

loans.name: Ni Putu Wartini

texts.id:
Ni Putu Wartini is in the business of pig farming. From her 1st loan with Dinari, she bought a breeding pig. She was able to earn a net profit of IDR 1 million in a 6 month period (around USD 112). However she feels that this income is still not enough to help her meet her family's needs. Therefore she is applying for the 2nd loan. She is planning to have 3 breeding pigs and she hopes she can sells the piglets 3 times in the next 6 months.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva volunteer.

Usaha Yang dirintis Ni Putu Wartini yaitu beternak babi karena usaha ini dapat berkembang cocok dengan lingkungannya. Dalam periode pinjaman ini Ni Putu Wartini masih memelihara 1 ekor induk babi, Keuntungan yang didapatnya dalam enam bulan dapat mencapai Rp 1.000.000.- .yang didapat dari penjualan bibit babi. Dalam setiap bulannya Ni Putu Wartini harus menyisihkan uang untuk biaya pemberian pakan ternaknya sekitar Rp.100.000,- Dari penghasilan 1 ekor induk babi ini, dirasa kurang mencukupi untuk biaya hidupnya. Karena itu, dalam pinjman kedua ini Wartini berencana memelihara tiga ekor induk babi dengan harapan dalam enam bulan Ni Putu Wartini dapat panen tiga kali dalam enam bulan, sehingga pendapatna keluarganya pun akan meningkat.

loans.use: To buy breeding pig (Membeli induk babi)

loans.name: Telesia

She has a previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 440 Tala (~183 USD).  SPBD loans are Telesia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  She's a mother of two children. Her husband is also unemployed like her, but working out on his taro plantation

loans.use: Purchase cabbages and cucumber seed, also for fertilizers and pots for planting.

loans.name: Faamaopo

texts.en: Faamaopo A. Y., 36, is married with 5 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the Elei Printing business. She sells to the general public 5 days per week. She has had a previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Faamaopo’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Faamaopo is a very hard working lady who works 5 days a week in trying to improve her business. She has five kids who are in school.

loans.use: Purchase printing boards, fabric paints, brush, glitters and rolls

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana N., 65, is married with 9 children.  She has year(s) of experience in the shop business. She sells to the   days per week. She has  previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be Tala (~0 USD).  SPBD loans are Susana’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase goods like mutton flaps,chicken,box of noodles etc.

loans.name: Gusti Ayu Ardiani

texts.id:
Gusti Ayu is a mother of two. She and her husband together with their children live a simple life. Gusti Ayu works as a manufacturing worker in a furniture factory, however her salary is not enough to meet her family's daily needs. Therefore around 6 months ago she decided to take for a loan from Dinari so she can afford to buy a breeding pig and to start a small pig breeding business as her side business.

With the loan money she bought 2 breeding female pigs which in turn can produce 18 piglets. These piglets were sold for IDR 250 thousand/ piglet (around USD 31/ piglet) so her revenue was IDR 4.5 million (around USD 562). This revenue was deducted with money spent for pig feed for a 6 month period of IDR 1.4 million (around USD 175), so she earned a net profit of USD 387 in a 6 month period.

Therefore she is now decided to again applying for the 2nd loan from Dinari so she can continue expanding her business. She hopes she can improve her family's welfare more and also to enable her to get more money for her's children school fees.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva volunteer.

Gusti Ayu Ardiyani adalah seorang wanita yang ulet dalam melakukan pekerjaannya. Dalam keadaan ekonomi sekarang yang semakin sulit, Gusti Ayu yang kesehariannya sebagai buruh mebel belumlah cukup untuk memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya yang terdiri dari suami dan 2 orang anaknya yang masih bersekolah. Dengan situasi seperti ini Gusti Ayu Ardiyani mengambil keputusan untuk ikut memelihara atau berternak babi. Melalui program DINARI, pada periode pinjaman pertama digunakan untuk membeli 2 ekor induk babi. Dari 2 ekor induk babi tersebut melahirkan 18 ekor anak babi dan bisa dijual dengan harga Rp. 250.000 / ekor. Dari 18 ekor anak babi tersebut diperoleh hasil penjualan sebesar Rp. 4.500.000.- / 6 bulan, yang dipotong untuk pakan induk sebesar Rp. 1.400.000.- / enam bulan. Jadi Gusti Ayu mendapatkan keuntungan sebesar Rp. 515.000.- / bulan. Dari hasil yang diperoleh dari pinjaman pertama tersebut Gusti Ayu memutuskan untuk kembali meminjam ke DINARI untuk meningkatkan penjualan anak babinya dengan menambah induk babi yang ada. Sehingga Gusti Ayu dapat meningkatkan penghasilan keluarganya untuk mencukupi kebutuhan keluarga dan untuk biaya anak sekolah.

loans.use: To buy breeding pig (Membeli induk babi)

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Vitoria , 35, is married with 6 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the Taro plantation business. She sells to the general public and villagers 2 days per week. She has had previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Vitoria’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Her husband helps out with the business and also does fishing at night time.

loans.use: To purchase pesticides.

loans.name: Ni Wayan Palma

texts.id:
Ni Wayan Palma was able to paid off her 1st loan with Dinari which was amounted to IDR 1.4 million (around USD 175) in a 6 month period. She also made a profit of USD 125 during that period, thanks to the opportunity provided to her by the loan.

She is now planning to more expanding her business by taking the 2nd loan from Dinari. She wants to buy more piglets and pig feed. She hopes her business can be more expanded to help her family's welfare.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva volunteer.

Setelah memperoleh hasil yang cukup lumayan dari pinjaman periode pertama dan dipengaruhi juga oleh semakin meningkatnya kebutuhan keluarga maka Wayan Palma memutuskan untuk melanjutkan dengan pinjaman periode kedua. Dari pinjaman pertama sebesar Rp. 1.400.000.- selama 6 bulan Wayan Palma meraup keuntungan sebesar Rp. 1000.000.- yang mana sangat membantu suaminya yang berprofesi sebagai petani musiman dalam memenuhi kebutuhan keluarganya. Semua ini bisa terjadi karena ketekunan Wayan Palma dan pendampingan secara rutin dari para staf DINARI. Melalui pinjaman periode kedua ini, Wayan Palma berharap bisa menambah jumlah babi peliharaannya dan juga akan dimanfaatkan untuk membeli pakan babi. Sehingga nantinya akan diperoleh keuntungan yang juga akan meningkat dan tentunya akan berpengaruh sangat besar untuk perekonomian keluarga.

loans.use: To buy piglet and pig feed (Membeli bibit dan pakan)

loans.name: Ni Kadek Adi Wartini

texts.id:
Kadek Adi Wartini has successfully paid off her first loan from Dinari. Her first loan was IDR 1.4 million (approximately of USD 175) and she was able to paid off this loan in 6 month period. Not only she was able to paid off her loan, she was also able to made a profit of IDR 1 million (Approx of USD 125).

With this result, she wants to take another loan to further expand her business. She is planning to use the loan money to buy more piglets and pig feed.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva volunteer.

Setelah menyelesaikan pinjaman periode pertama, Kadek Adi Wartini peternak babi asal Ekasari ini merasakan hasil yang diperolehnya cukup lumayan. Dari pinjaman pertama sebesar Rp. 1.400.000.- yang diterimanya 6 bulan lalu dari Dinari, Kadek Adi Wartini mampu memperoleh keuntungan bersih Rp.1000.000.-. Dengan hasil bagus yang dicapai oleh Kadek Adi Wartini disertai pembinaan yang rutin dilaksanakan oleh staf DINARI memacu Kadek Adi Wartini untuk melanjutkan pinjaman ke periode kedua dengan jumlah yang sama untuk nantinya akan dimanfaatkan untuk menambah jumlah babi dan membeli pakannya. Dari hasil beternak babi yang ditekuni Kadek Adi Wartini ini bisa memenuhi kebutuhan keluarga sehari-hari dan sedikit disisihkan untuk ditabung supaya bisa menambah modal usaha yang dikembangkan oleh Kadek Adi Wartini.

loans.use: To buy piglet and pig feed (Membeli bibit dan pakan)

loans.name: Mesi

texts.en: Mesi S., 47, is married with 4 children.  She has 3 years of experience in general business. She sells to the village and general public 6 days per week. She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Mesi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She wants to improve business and accommodate her family needs.

loans.use: To purchase ice cakes, pancakes, pork cakes, etc

loans.name: Ni Ketut Ariastuti

texts.id:
Raising pigs is a work that makes Ni Ketut Ariastuti happy especially with the satisfactory results from DINARI's first loan where from sales of 4 pigs that she raised for 6 months, Ketut Ariastuti obtain a Rp900,000 profit (Translator’s note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp8,000-9,500.00). This motivates Ketut Ariastuti to again borrow capital from DINARI for second phase, where she expects better results than from first loan. This second loan will be used to buy piglets, feed and also medicine. From first loan profit, Ketut Ariastuti could fulfill family needs, and also used to expand her pig farming to the next phase, and with DINARI's laon also hopes that number of pig raised could also increase.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Memelihara babi merupakan pekerjaan yang menyenangkan bagi Ni Ketut Ariastuti apalagi setelah mendapatkan hasil yang memuaskan dari pinjaman pertama ke DINARI, dimana dari hasil penjualan 4 ekor babi yang dipeliharanya selama 6 bulan Ketut Ariastuti memperoleh keuntungan sebesar Rp. 900.000.-. Tentunya hasil ini memotivasi Ketut Ariastuti untuk kembali meminjam modal ke DINARI pada tahap kedua yang nantinya diharapkan akan memberikan hasil yang lebih baik dari pinjaman pertama. Dimana pinjaman kedua ini akan dibelikan bibit babi serta pakan disamping untuk obat juga. Dari keuntungan yang diperoleh pada pinjaman periode pertama Ketut Ariastuti mampu mencukupi kebutuhan keluarganya serta bisa dipakai juga untuk pengembangan ternak babi pada tahap selanjutnya dan ditambah dengan pinjaman dari DINARI maka diharapkan jumlah babi yang dipelihara akan bertambah juga.

loans.use: To buy piglets and feed (Membeli bibit dan pakan)

loans.name: Ni Made Gelis

texts.id:
Ni Made Gelis enjoys her work as pig farmewr, since besides providing income as pig farmer, also gives her recreation besides being a housewife. From DINARI's first loan, Made Gelis bought one mother pig, that after 6 months bore 6 piglets. From sales of those 10 piglets, Made Gelis profits Rp 1,100,000 (Translator’s note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp8,000-9,500.00) after subtracting feed and medical expenses. After learning of that good result, Made Gelis is requesting a second perod loan from DINARI to increase her capital to buy a second mother pig. So that in the next 6 months she could obtain more result than from her first loan. Of course Made Gelis' hope that this second period loan could be useful for her family in the niddle of ever increasing prices of all major daily needs items.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Made Gelis sangat menikmati pekerjaannya sebagai peternak babi karena disamping menghasilkan pendapatan bagi keluarga beternak babi juga sebagai hiburan disela-sela kegiatannya sebagai ibu rumah tangga. Dari pinjaman pertama ke DINARI Made Gelis membeli 1 ekor induk babi yang setelah 6 bulan melahirkan 10 ekor anak babi. Dari hasil penjualan 10 ekor anak babi tersebut Made Gelis memperoleh keuntungan bersih sebesar Rp. 1.100.000 dan itu sudah dipotong biaya pakan dan obat. Setelah mengetahui hasil yang demikian bagus itu, Made Gelis kembali melakukan pinjaman periode kedua ke DINARI untuk menambah modalnya untuk membeli induk babi menjadi 2 ekor. Sehingga kedepannya selama 6 bulan akan diperoleh hasil yang melebihi dari pinjaman pertama. Tentunya besar harapan dari Made Gelis pada periode kedua ini hasil yang akan diperoleh akan sangat bermafaat bagi keluarganya ditengah semakin tingginya semua harga bahan pokok keperluan sehari-hari.

loans.use: To buy mother pig (Membeli induk babi)

loans.name: Orita

texts.en: Orita F., 31, is married with 1 child.  She has 2 years of experience in the groceries business. She sells to the village and general public 7 days per week. She has had 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD).  SPBD loans are Orita’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to upgrade the business status. Her husband also helps out with the business.

loans.use: To purchase general stocks

loans.name: Uimaiama

She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Uimaiama’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to upgrade her business status. Her husband and children help by working on the plantation.

loans.use: To purchase ice cakes, pancakes, pork cakes, etc

SPBD loans are Sifaga’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will also help her with her many family obligations. Her husband also helps out with the business.

She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Tausoa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will also help her with her many family obligations. Her husband also helps out with the business.

texts.en: Lise U., 36, is married with 5 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the food stall business. She sells to the villagers 5 days per week. She has had previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 320 Tala (~133 USD).  SPBD loans are Lise’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Her husband also helps out with business.

loans.use: For purchasing ingredients for her preparation

loans.name: Faatupu

texts.en: Faatupu Pasi, 57, is married with 6 children.  She has many years of experience in the shop business. She sells to the villagers 7 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).  SPBD loans are Faatupu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  She is a mother of six children running a small shop.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Pua

texts.en: Pua L., 43, is married with 6 children.  She has many years of experience in the fish business. She sells to the villagers and the general public 3 days per week. She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 550 Tala (~229 USD).  SPBD loans are Pua’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will also help her with her many family obligations. Her husband does the fishing duty.

loans.use: To help with business upgrading, house repair, and her children's education

loans.name: Talita

texts.en: Talita Foleni, 33, is married with 2 children.  She has many years of experience in the fish business. She sells to the villagers and the general public 4 days per week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD).  SPBD loans are Talita’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will also help her with her many family obligations. Her husband does the fishing duty.

loans.use: To buy an extra pair of fishing shoes for her husband, a fishing net, and to make home repairs.

loans.name: Iliganoa

texts.en: Iliganoa A., 36, is married with 3 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the pancakes, pork cakes, and ice cakes business. She sells to the villagers and general public 5 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Iliganoa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will also help her with her many family obligations. Her husband works as a laborer for the Government and also helps out with the business.

loans.use: To buy materials to start a business i.e.  bag of flour, bag of sugar, box mutton flaps, and flavorings

loans.name: Palepa

texts.en: Palepa I., 35, is married with 4 children.  She has many years of experience in the groceries and food items business. She sells to the villagers and general public 7 days per week. She has had 4 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (~250 USD).  SPBD loans are Palepa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her earnings will also help her with her many family obligations and she will save some for the rainy days. Her husband is self employed working on the plantation, and fishing as well.

loans.use: To restock her shop and buy a fishing net, as an alternative source of income

loans.name: Wiwin Puji

texts.id:
Wiwin's daily business is cooked rice slaes. Her food stall is already open for several years, however up to now has not expanded as expected. Actually the business is promising, since many people stop at her food stall. However, since the menu is always the same, many got bored. Therefore she hopes to obtain a loan to be used as business capital to increase food selections, so that more customers would eat at her food stall. Every day she goes to the closest market using a motor cycle driven by her husband, Heri Basuki. Right now with family and two children, Wiwin lives in Dalung Permai Denpasar by renting land and build a simple house on it.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Usaha yang dilakukan sehari-hari Wiwin adalah sebagai penjual nasi. Warung makanan miliknya sedah berdiri sejak beberapa tahun yang lalu, tetapi hingga sekarang belum juga mengalami perkembangan yang menjanjikan. Usaha yang dijalaninya sebenarnya cukup menjanjikan, karena banyak orang yang mampir kewarungnya. Tetapi karena menu makanannya selalu sama, banyak yang merasa bosan. Oleh karena itu dia sangat mengharapkan mendapat pinjaman untuk nantinya dijadikan modal usahanya, untuk memperbanyak jenis makanan sehingga nantinya semakin banyak pelanggan yang makan diwarungnya. Setiap harinya dia harus berangkat ke Pasar terdekat dengan mengendarai sepeda motor dengan diantar oleh suaminya, Heri Basuki. Saat ini, bersama keluarga dan kedua anaknya, Wiwin tinggal di Dalung Permai Denpasar dengan mengontrak sebidang tanah dan membangun rumah sederhana diatasnya.

loans.use: To add business capital (Menambah Modal Usaha)

loans.name: Taimoe

texts.en: Taimoe H., 40, is married with 3 children.  She has many years of experience in the Taro, taamu, bananas and yams business. She sells to the public and villagers 3 days per week. She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).  SPBD loans are Taimoe’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her earnings to improve the business and pay for the children's school fees.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Fransiska

texts.id:
Fransiska is a lady who owns packed rice business. At this moment Fransiska still stays in a rented room with her 2 school aged children. Fransiska wishes to get the loan help to open a food stall near her rented room, since up to now Fransiska does not have a place to sell her cooked rice. Every day she has to travel around to offer her packed rice from one place to another. She very much hope with DINARI's help this time to be used as capital addition to rent a stall, so that her business could expand. With higher profit, she likes to send her two children to school. At this moment with husband I Nyoman Udayana and 2 children, they live in Kebo Iwa street Denpasar.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Fransiska adalah seorang ibu rumah tangga yang memiliki usaha jualan nasi bungkus. Saat ini Fransiska masih tinggal di tempat kost dengan harus menanggung 2 orang anaknya yang masih sekolah. Melalui DINARI, Fransiska berkeinginan mendapat bantuan modal usaha untuk membuka warung nasi didekat tempat kostnya, karena sampai saat ini Fransiska belum mempunyai tempat untuk berjualan nasi. Setiapa harinya, dia harus berkeliling menjajakan nasi bungkus, dari satu tempat ke tempat yang lain. Dia sangat berharap, dengan bantuan dari DINARI kali ini, bisa dipakai sebagai modal untuk menyewa tempat berjualan, sehingga nantinya usaha ini bisa lebih berkembang. Dengan keuntungan yang lebih besar, dia ingin menyekolahkan kedua anaknya. Saat ini bersama suaminya I Nyoman Udayana dan ke 2 anaknya, mereka tinggal di Jl. Kebo Iwa Denpasar.

loans.use: To open own Food stall (Membuka warung sendiri)

loans.name: Mele

texts.en: Mele P., 46, is married with 9 children.  She has many years of experience in the bananas, taro, taamu and yams business. She sells to the public and villagers 2 days per week. She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  SPBD loans are Mele’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Also, she will use the loan for buying timbers, iron roofs and cement for home improvements.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Puch

texts.en:
Sun Han, age 58, is a housewife and her husband Mr. Puch T. operates a motor-taxi business. This couple has 8 children and lives in Siem Reap province. (Mrs. Sun is pictured.)

Sun’s husband earns $2 profit per day to support his family. This amount is not adequate to meet daily expenses, so they plan in the future to open a small stand in front of their house, and sell groceries and produce. But right now, they plan to fix the leaking roof, which is very bad in raining season. They would like a loan from Kiva to purchase wood to repair the leaking roof.

loans.use: To open a small stand selling groceries, and repair leaking roof

loans.name: Falatika

texts.en: Falatika A., 64, is married with 7 children.  She has many years of experience in the taro and taamu business. She sells to the public and villagers 2 days per week. She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Falatika’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Also, she will use the loan for buying cement and timber for repairing her home.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Nop El Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Nop E. is the group leader of six in Kanh Chong Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She buys a Kor fruit which can be made into pillows in Cambodia. Her husband, Mr. YuS. Sal, is a subsistence farmer. They have one child who is enrolling in state school.

Over time, Mrs. Nop E.’s business activity has improved so she now wants to expand it. Unfortunately, Mrs. Nop E. does not have enough money to buy Kor fruit so she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Previously, Mrs. Nop E. obtained a loan to start her business. Mr. Him S.'s wife will receive the loan instead of Mr. Him S., so only she is shown in the photo.

loans.use: To buy Kor fruit in order to expand her business.

loans.name: Tep

texts.en:
Tep V. sells rice soup from her house in Tasa Village in the Pursat Province, Cambodia and earns average income of $1 per day. She always wakes up early morning to boil her rice soup to sell customers on time. She is married and lives with two children, all of whom are small and attend school. Her husband, Mr. Nov Phat, 34, is a commune policeman and has an average income of $2.5 per day. 
With a desire to sustain and expand her business, now V. is seeking a loan to purchase ingredients for her rice soup business and to use the remainder of the loan to buy groceries for her expanding business.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for rice soup business and buy groceries for her expanding business

loans.name: Moa

texts.en:
Moa H. is 40 years old, and has worked selling charcoal and fire wood in Siem Reap since 1995. She makes $1 a day. (Mrs. Moa is pictured.)

Her husband is employed by a tourist company to look after the temple. His job is to check the tickets of the tourists who visit the temple area. Two of their oldest children sell souvenirs in front of the temple and make $3 per day.

This couple would like a loan from Kiva to purchase wood to repair the leaky roof, which makes living very difficult in the rainy season.

loans.use: To purchase wood to repair the leaky roof

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Aufaatasi

texts.en: Aufaatasi J., 56, is widowed with 5 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the taro and taamu business. She sells to the public and villagers 5 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD).  SPBD loans are Aufaatasi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  She also uses loans for improving her flea market where she sells fruits, vegetables and chips.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Thy Yin Group

texts.en:
Four members in Ka Art Village make up a group loan; Mrs. Thy Y. is the group leader. She is a coal seller in the village. Her business is now more improved so Mrs. Thy Y. needs to expand her business in order to make the family more successful. Thus, Mrs. Thy Y. asked for a loan to buy more coals to re-sell.

Her husband, Mr. Sothearou Krouch, is a coal seller and lottery seller. Mrs. Thy Y. is 24 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending a local school while the other is too young to work or study. Previously, Mrs. Thy Y. obtained a loan to start a coal business.

loans.use: To buy more coals to re-sell for an income.

loans.name: Von Bu Group

texts.en:
Mr. Von B. is the group leader of four in Ka Art village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a teacher in state school. Her husband, Mrs. Sokunthea Hem, is employed in a garment factory.

Together, they try to generate money to support the family but the family is still living in poor condition. Even the house is too old so Mr. Von B. now wants to build a new house. Unfortunately, he has insufficient money to build it. Thus, Mr. Von B. decided to ask for a loan to add with his profit to build it to replace an old one.

loans.use: To build a new house to replace an old one.

loans.name: Alieta

texts.en: Alieta Paio, 42, is married with 6 children.  She has many years of experience in the taro, taamu and banana business. She sells to the public/villagers 2 days per week. She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Alieta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  She also has her ice-cake business and sells at the village school and to villagers.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Sreyoun Sam Group

texts.en:
A group that consists of four members is in Ka Art Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Sreyoun S. is the group leader and she owns a small grocery store in the village.

In her business, Mrs. Sreyoun S. has faced a small problem because she does not have enough money to purchase more grocery products. Thus, Mrs. Sreyoun S. asked for a loan for this purpose.

Mrs. Sreyoun S. is 24 years old and the mother of one child who is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Chanphakdey Pin, always assists his wife’s business. Previously, Mrs. Sreyoun S. obtained a loan to start her business.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to re-sell to her customers.

loans.name: Tafale

texts.en: Tafale A., 46, is married with 9 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the taro and banana business. She sells to the public and villagers 3 days per week. She has received one previous loan from SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (approximately 208 USD).  SPBD loans are Tafale’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  She also has a vegetable garden as part of her business.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Puy

texts.en:
Phum Ban, age 23, is a housewife. Since 1998, her husband, Mr. Puy C., has had a business hiring a grinding mill for the local people to take off the husks on rice. Most of the people in the village are poor. They do not have enough money to own a grinding machine, so they have to hire Phum's family whenever take have to take the husks off the rice. Mr. Puy earns $2 per day. This couple has one child. (Phum's husband is pictured with a grinding mill.)

To reduce the amount of money they spend on transportation, they would like a loan from Kiva to purchase a motor bike. They also plan to purchase some wood to fix their leaky house.

loans.use: To purchase a motor bike to reduce transporation costs, and some wood to fix their leaky house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Elieta

texts.en: Elieta F., 35, is married with 7 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the pancake and pork bun business. She sells to the village school and villagers 3 days per week. She has received one previous loan from SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (approximately 145 USD).  SPBD loans are Elieta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Her husband also helps out with running the business, as well as with the loan repayments.

loans.use: To buy ingredients such as flour, yeast, drippings, and meat

loans.name: Tofu

texts.en: Tofu L., 51, is divorced with 6 children.  She has 4 years of experience in the potted plants and flowers business. She sells to the public and villagers 3 days per week. She has received 3 previous loans from SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (approximately 208 USD).  SPBD loans are Tofu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will also use the loan to buy cement and timber for home repairs. Three of her children are assisting her with her business.

loans.use: Purchase new potted plants, fertilizers, tools and plastic bags

loans.name: Yong

texts.en: Yong R. is a widow grocery seller in Oreusey Village in the Pursat Province. She has eight children, one of whom is married. With her large family, R. cannot support her family expenses sufficiently so her children decided go out to find jobs to help support family. Now two sons are working as construction workers and others made a business of selling groceries. With her business growing, R. is seeking a loan to purchase more grocery stock for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery stock for her business

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria N., 37, is married with 3 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the taro plantation business, and she sells to the village people and the public 3 days per week. She has received no previous loan from SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (approximately 160 USD).  SPBD loans are Maria’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband is involved in farming.

loans.use: Improve her taro plantation business

loans.name: Valeai

texts.en: Vaoa Gaui, 32, is married with 2 children.  She has 2 year(s) of experience in the Taro and Banana Plantation business. She sells to the the general public and villagers 2 days per week. She has 2 previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~104 USD).  SPBD loans are Vaoa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use part of her loan for home improvements

loans.use: Purchase taro tubers, weed killers, pesticides, chemicals and a shovel, bricks, cement, timber, nails, paint, iron roofing

loans.name: Faamuamaga

texts.en: Valeai Suataai, 38, is married with 7 children.  She has 2 year(s) of experience in the Taro, taamu and bananas business. She sells to the public and villagers 2 days per week. She has 2 previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD).  SPBD loans are Valeai’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Also use for buying cements and timbers for home repairing

loans.use: buy chemicals and pesticides, timber, iron roofing, nails, cement, bricks, furnitures

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria E., 73, is married with 4 children.  She has 3 years of experience in running a shop. She sells to the village people and the public 2 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (approximately 208 USD).  SPBD loans are Maria’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used for house repairs. Her husband does the farming.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Leoi

texts.en: Leoi S., 32, is married with 2 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the taro plantation business, and she sells to the village people and public 3 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (approximately 250 USD).  SPBD loans are Leoi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used to pay for her children's schooling. Her husband farms to support the family.

loans.use: To maintain business improvement

loans.name: Sinaleimoa

texts.en: Sinaleimoa T., 40, is married with 4 children.  She has 1 year of experience in the taro plantation business. She sells to the village people and public 4 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (approximately 250 USD).  SPBD loans are Sinaleimoa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use all of the loan to start her business. Her husband is involved in farming.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals and equipment needed for the plantation.

loans.name: Apaula

texts.en: Apaula K., 55, is married with 5 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the ice-cake/chips business. She sells to the school children and village people 7 days per week. Her business was already funded by her first loan from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (approximately 250 USD).  SPBD loans are Apaula’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use all of the loan to support her business needs. Her husband is helping her to operate the business.

loans.use: To purchase items needed for the business.

loans.name: Dao Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Dao Thi T., 37 years old, is a very special case. Her husband passed away and she does not have any children. She is currently living with her old mother. Therefore, she is responsible for all the housework. She always tries her best to better her living situation. She joined the TYM Fund to borrow money and invest in breeding animals. Over the time, she diligently took care of her project and earned lots of breeding experience. She used both her saving money and borrowed money to expand her breeding plan. She was successful and her family economy experienced improvement. This time she wants to borrow 375 USD. Her average income is approximately 100 USD/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Dào Thị Tươi 37 tuổi, có hoàn cảnh gia đình đặc biệt không giống các chị em khác, chồng mất sớm bản thân chị lại chưa có con, hiện tai chị đang sống cùng mẹ già, mọi công việc trong gia đình đều chút lên đôi vai chị, biết được số phận của mình như vây chị luôn có ý thức vươn lên. Chị tham gia vào Quỹ vay vốn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi, tần tảo chịu thương chịu khó chăm sóc dự án của mình chị cũng đã thành công trong việc chăn nuôi, dần dần chị đã tích lũy được kinh nghiệm trong chăn nuôi, và đã có chút vốn tiết kiệm kết hợp với việc vay vốn của Quỹ, chị mạnh giạn mở rộng mô hình chăn nuôi, với mô hình chăn nuôi đó chị đều thành công và kinh tế gia đình đã thay đổi, từ lúc khó khăn nay đã gia đình đã khá hơn rất nhiều. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 6.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi.Thu nhập bình quân 1.500.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Pigs

loans.name: Phun

texts.en:
Phun R. is a 56-year-old mother of 6 children. One child is a waiter in a hotel, and two are married and live away fR. home. (Phun is pictured with her daughter.)

Since 2004, Phun has worked as a land dealer. She goes fR. house to house and asks whether the family wants to sell land or a house. If someone needs to purchase land, they often go to Mrs. Phon, because she is very knowledgeable. On average, she earns around $5 per day. Her husband sells Khmer traditional medicine. He earn about $3 per day.

Mrs. Phun R. is requesting a loan fR. Kiva to purchase a motor bike. She plans to use this motor bike to travel everywhere to search for families who want to sell their land or house.

loans.use: To purchase a motor bike

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Mal

texts.en:
Mal L., age 27, is married with two children and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. (Mal is pictured with her child.)

She and her husband have different jobs. Since 2001, Mal has worked selling fish in the market, and earns around $5 per day. Mal’s husband is a construction worker who builds houses. He also does construction work around his village. Sometimes he has to leave his village to find a construction work. He earns $5 per day.

Mal is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a motor bike for her husband to commute to work. She plans to use the rest of money to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motor bike and increase the number of selling fish.

loans.name: Kalala

texts.en: Kalala V., 37, is married with 4 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the taro plantation business. She sells to the village people and the public 4 days per week. This will be her third loan from SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (approximately 208 USD).  SPBD loans are Kalala’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will be used to pay for her kids' school fees. Her husband is involved in farming.

loans.use: To maintain business needs.

loans.name: Naeem's Group

texts.en:
Naeem B., wife of M., lives in a small city named Arifwala in Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house. She is a mother of one daughter, who is 13 years old, named Saima Parvez. Saima is in the 4th standard grade and wants to be a teacher. Naseem and her husband Parvez want to fulfill their daughter’s wish. Her husband is a fruit seller. He has been in this profession for the last 20 years. Naeem successfully completed her frist loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. She applies for this loan for her husband’s fruit business.

She has been joined in her group by a few more members. Kalsoom B. wants a loan for her cosmetic business. Safia B. wants a loan for her husband’s shoe business. Zahida B. wants a loan for repairing her husband’s auto-rickshaw. Bilquis B. wants a loan for her shoe business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To improve the financial condition of the businesses

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra B., wife of J. D., lives in a small city named Arifwala in Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house. She is a mother of two children: one daughter, Fize, and one son, Rehan. Both are in the 2nd standard grade. Azra’s husband is a milk man. He has been in this profession for the last 12 years. Azra successfully completed her first loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. She applies for this loan for her husband, who wants to buy a buffalo for his milk business.

She has been joined in her group by a few more members. Naseem B. wants a loan for her food business. Zareena B. wants a loan for her husband’s legal paper business. Kaneez B. wants a loan for her wheat selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To improve their financial situations

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa A. S., 39, is married with 1 child.  She has 2 years of experience in the Canteen/Bingo business. Her canteen sells to the schools, but bingo will be held in the village 5 days per week. This is her second loan from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 700 Tala (approximately 291 USD).  SPBD loans are Theresa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband has left already for New Zealand.

loans.use: To fund her canteen/bingo business

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Chea Chanthea, age 26, has one child and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. After her housework is done, she works selling dessert in a busy market. She earns $5 per day. (Chea is pictured.)

Her husband, Kong S., is a motor-taxi driver. He normally takes a guest from the hotel and goes around the temple in Siem Reap. He also gives a one-day tour for tourists for $15. On average, he earns $8 per day.

To earn more money, Chea’s husband is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase another motor-taxi. He plans to rent this motor-taxi to earn extra income.

loans.use: To purchase a motor taxi to rent for extra income

loans.name: Anwari's Group

texts.en:
Anwari B., wife of Z. A., lives in a small city named Arifwala in Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house. She is a mother of two children: one daughter, Waheed, and one son, Hadia. Waheed is in the 9th standard grade. Hadia is in the 6th standard grade.  Anwari’s husband makes plastic sheets. He has been in this profession for the last 25 years and sells his work to different areas and cities. Anwari B. successfully completed her frist loan from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. She applies for this loan for her husband’s plastic sheets business.

She has been joined in her group by a few more members. Razia B. wants a loan for her wheat selling business. Kaneez B. wants a loan for her scrap work. Shamshad B. wants a loan for her livestock business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Valasiolagi

texts.en: Valasiolagi B., 35, is married with 3 children.  She has many years of experience in the grocery business. She sells to the village community and district 7 days per week. She has received one previous loan from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (approximately 100 USD).  SPBD loans are Valasiolagi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use part of her loan to assist her with her children's school needs, and buy new equipment. Her husband has done the hard and dirty work of planning her business.

loans.use: Purchase things to improve her business

loans.name: Hafizan's Group

texts.en:
Hafizan B. is a widow of T. H.. She lives in a small city named Arifwala in Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house. She is a mother of five children. She has three sons: Hassan, who is in the 3rd standard grade, Rashid Ali who completed eight grades of education and started a flower business, and Kashif, who also completed eight grades of education and is a salesman. Hafizan’s two daughters are Sania, who is 17-years-old and is in the 10th standard grade, and Bushra, who is 15 years old and in the 6th standard grade. Hafizan is a housewife. She applied for this loan for her son’s flower business.

She has been joined in her group by a few more members. Nazia B. wants a loan for her utensils' business. Kaneez B. wants a loan for her wheat business. Rukhsana B. wants a loan for her plastic bottles business. Haleeman B. wants a loan for her medical clinic.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Moung

texts.en:
Moung S., 40, has worked as a Khmer traditional massage girl since 2000. She earns $3 per day. (Moung is pictured.)

Her husband earns $5 per day from his motor taxi business. This couple has 6 children: 2 are married and live away from home; the others are students. She and her husband work very hard to support the children's education expenses. They spend almost $2 per day for their children to go to school.

To earn more money for the family, they are requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase and raise pigs. They plan to use the rest of money to finish construction of their house.

loans.use: To raise pigs, and complete construction of their house.

loans.name: Mai Thi

texts.vi:
From the first days that the Fund was announced in her hometown, Mrs. K. Thi Mai had started planning with her husband, Thanh Van Nguyen, to join the Tinh Thuong Fund which focuses entirely on agricultural ventures. From then on the couple decided to borrow money to invest in raising livestock. In every funding round the couple had used the money to invest in livestock. With this focus, the family’s finances have improved markedly and they have been able to afford more conveniences. Mrs. Mai’s son earns an average of 2,500,000 VND per month from his work, and this amount is used to make the weekly payment to the Fund. Extra income is put towards larger and more important uses. In this round of funding the family is requesting 13,000,000 VND to invest in raising pigs. The family’s average income is 4,000,000 per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Ngay từ nhưng ngày đầu Quỹ triển khai trên địa bàn thôn nhà, chị Mai Thị Kiềm đã bàn bạc cùng chồng là anh Nguyễn Văn Thanh, tham gia vào Quỹ Tình Thương, với một địa phương thuần nông nguồn thu nhập chính hoàn toàn phụ thuộc vào nông nghiệp. Từ đó việc vay vốn sử dụng vào mục đích chăn nuôi được anh chị lựa chọn đầu tiên. Các vòng vốn vay của Quỹ anh chị đều đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Với việc lựa chọn mô hình chăn nuôi kính tế gia đình anh chị phát triển rõ rệt, sinh hoạt gia đình đã được cải thiện hơn, mua sắm được nhiều tiện nghi có giá trị, con trai chị đi làm thu nhập bình quân 2.500.000đ/ tháng, số tiền này gia đình dùng vào việc trả tiền tuần cho Quỹ, thu nhập từ dự án được gia đình sử dụng vào các việc lớn. Vòng vốn này gia đình xin vay 13.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn. Thu nhập bình quân 4.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Pigs

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia B. is a wife of M.. She lives in a small city named Arifwala in Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house. She is a mother of three children, two sons and one daughter. Her first son, Awais, is in the 3rd standard grade. Her second son, Waqas, is in the 2nd standard grade. Razia’s daughter is named Nargis. She is 14-years-old and does not go to school. Razia’s husband is a trader by profession. He has been in this profession for the last 20 years. He buys livestock from different cities and sells them to the customers. Therefore, Razia has applied for this loan for her husband’s livestock business.

She has been joined in her group by a few more members. Latifan B. wants a loan to repair her vehicle, an auto-rickshaw. Anwari B. wants a loan for her stove business. Anwari B. wants a loan for her shoe cart business. Rubina B. wants a loan for her fruit cart business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Huseinova

texts.ru:
A. Huseinova is a young woman of 28, she is not married and lives with her parents. She works as a seamstress in a sewing factory. Besides her job she also helps her father with the cattle. Her parents are retired. A. loves taking care of the cattle, she walks and washes them on the weekends. At this time she has two cows and wants to buy two bigger ones when she receives a loan. She needs a loan of 3,500 somoni (US$1,025).

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Хусейнова Анора девушка в возросте 28 лет не замужем , живет с родителями. Работает закройщией в швейном цехе.По мимо работы она помогает отцу по уходу за скотом.Мать и отец Аноры пенсионеры, ни где не работают. Анора очень любит скот и уход за ним, по выходным она выводит их на прогулку , купает .На данное ремя у нее сейчас двое коров , получив кредит она хочет купить еще пару больших коров.Она хочет получить 3500 сомони.

loans.use: Feeding and selling of cattle

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en:
Oeun H., age 42, is a farmer who plants rice and vegetables. Her husband owns a trailer and transfers sand and rocks to construction sites. Together, this husband and wife earn $20 per day. This couple has four children, 3 of whom are students and one helps his mother on the farm.

Mrs. Oeun is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a water pump, ric, and vegetable seeds to grow for next year. When she has a water pump, she can irrigate her crop without depending on rain.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump, rice, and vegetable seeds

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Sootino

texts.en: Sootino F., 33, is single with no children.  She has many years of experience in the grocery business. She sells to the village community district 6 days per week. She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be $187 USD.  SPBD loans are Sootino’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of the profits will be used to pay children's education fees. Sootino is a single woman but she contributes to the needs of all the children in her extended family .

loans.use: The loan will be used for purchasing sack s of flour, boxes  of cooking oil,sacks of rice,sacks of baking powder,boxes  of deodorant and canned fish.

loans.name: Faaofo

texts.en: Faaofo M., 59, is married with 6 children.  She has many years of experience in the taro/banana/cows business. She sells to the village community / District 3 days per week. She has 5 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be $125 USD.  SPBD loans are Faaofo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use part of her loan to assist her with her children's school needs,and for buying new equipment.

loans.use: The  loan will be used for replacing all tool; shovels ,bush knives,wheelbarrows,spades ,axes and  also coromozone chemicals etc

loans.name: Art

texts.en:
Art Hak Seng, a 35-year-old, is a Tuk Tuk driver in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. A Tuk Tuk is a cart pulled by a motor bike. People, especially foreigners, really like this kind of transportation because it is safer that a normal motor bike. Siem Reap is one of the beautiful provinces in Cambodia, and there are many famous temple that survived attacks by the foreigners.

On average, he makes $9 per day. His wife is a housewife and stays at home looking after their two children and cooking food for the whole family. (Pictured: husband, wife, and their son)

This couple are requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase construction materials to build a stable house. Right now they have a thatch-wall house and this will not be safe if there is a big storm. The new house will provide better accommodations for the family. In the future, this couple plans to raise pigs to earn extra income.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials to make a sturdier house

loans.name: Alatupe

texts.en: Alatupe T., 56, is married with 2 children.  She has had many years of experience in the Taro/bananas business. She sells to the village community and also at the market during peak season 3 days per week. She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 $125 USD.  SPBD loans are Alatupe’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Alatupe has used the loans to improve the business and help out in paying her children's school fees.

loans.use: She will use all of her loan to pay for all overhead costs of her business

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is a 24-year old married woman with a lot of experience in elei printing (a traditional Samoan way of printing fabrics). Before, she never had the initative to turn her hobby and talent into a business but through friends that have been loaning with SPBD, she has then decided to have a go at it and see how she will manage in operating such a business.Therefore this loan will use to improve her business.

loans.use: caved design, paint, and raw materials.

loans.name: Sary Yop Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sary Y. is the group leader of six members in the Ka Art Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She hires a big tent to the people who hold a party, wedding ceremony or funeral. Her husband, Mr. Phon Nov, is employed in his wife’s business activity.

Mrs. Sary Y. has four children, one of whom hires a loudspeaker to the party or wedding ceremony while the three others are studying at state school. Mrs. Sary Y.’s business is now better improved so she now wants to expand her business. Thus, she is asking for a loan to buy more tents to rent for gatherings.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more tents to rent it.

loans.name: Moana

texts.en: Moana  F. , 39, is married with 3 children.  She has had many years of experience in the taro/bananas business. She sells to the village community/District 2 days per week. She has had 4 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be  $125 USD.  SPBD loans are Moana’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.  Moana's husband helps out in maintaining the plantation.

loans.use: The loan will be used to purchase all equipment for her plantation; bush knives,shovels ,axes. wheelbarrows, spades, pesticides and chemicals.

loans.name: Afioga

texts.en: Afioga M., 34, is married with 2 children.  She has many year(s) of experience in the cocoa business. She sells to the villagers/public 4 days per week. She has no previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  SPBD loans are Afioga’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. This is her first loan with the SPBD and will help her to generate her business.

loans.use: sacks of cocoa beans, plastic cups and bags.

loans.name: Lonise

texts.en: Lonise G., 65, is married with 7 children.  She has many years of experience in the clothing business. She sells to the village community and also town area shops 4 days per week. She has had 7 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be $187 USD).  SPBD loans are Lonise’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan to improve her business and to help out in paying her children's school fees.

loans.use: Purchase new sewing machine of overlock brand ,thread , and all materials for sewing

loans.name: Yong Leom Group

texts.en:
Five members in Chrok Kov Village in Kampong Chhnang Province have formed a group loan. Mrs. Yong L. is the group leader and she is a farmer who grows only vegetables. Her business now is improved so at this time, Mrs. Yong L. wishes to expand her business.

Thus, she is asking for a loan to purchase more watermelon seeds to cultivate on her field. Her husband, Mr. Soy Sok, is a subsistence farmer and woodman. Mrs. Yong L. is 42 years old and the mother of three children; one of whom is attending a local school while the two others stay at home because they are too young.

loans.use: To purchase more watermelon seeds to cultivate on her field.

loans.name: Tagisia

texts.en: Tagisia T., 28, is married with 1 children.  She has 5 year(s) of experience in the keke puaa business. She sells to the villagers/public 5 days per week. She has no previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  SPBD loans are Tagisia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will help her assist in buying tools for her business.

loans.use: stove,frying pan,20litre oil and case of mutton flaps.

loans.name: Ngo Thi

texts.vi:
Ms. B. Thi Ngo, 51 years old, joined the Fund in 2002 with the goal of expanding her business. In previous funding rounds, her family invested in raising pigs and chicken. She is an empathic and hard working person who is always willing to learn. Her family is very successful at raising livestock, the family’s finances have improved steadily and they have been able to afford more necessities like a vehicle, refrigerator, etc. Besides the income from raising livestock, the family also has a steady income from her husband’s herbal medicine business; having this reliable income encouraged the family to go with the weekly payment borrowing method, since it fit their needs well. In this round of funding the family is requesting 15,000,000 VND to continue investing in raising pigs and chicken. The family’s average income is 2,000,000 VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Ngọ Thị Bốn, năm nay 51 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ Tình Thương năm 2002, với mục đích vay vốn phát triển kinh tế, các vòng vốn trước gia đình chị đầu tư vốn vào chăn nuôi lợn, gà. Với bản chất chịu thương chịu khó ham học hỏi, gia đình chị chăn nuôi rất thuận lợi, từ đó kinh tế gia đình chị ngày càng phát triển và đã mua sắm được các trang thiết bị cần thiết cho gia đình như xe máy, tủ lạnh .......Ngoài việc thu nhập từ chăn nuôi, gia đình chị còn có nguồn thu đều đặn chồng chị làm nghề bốc thuốc bắc, chính từ nguồn thu đều đặn này mà gia đình chị thấy việc hoàn trả theo tuần là rất phù hợp. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 15.000.000đ đầu tư tiếp vào chăn nuôi lợn. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình 2.000.000đ/tháng.

loans.use: feed pigs

loans.name: Fesuiai

texts.en: Fesuiai T., 45, is married with 4 children.  She has many years of experience in the Samoan Cocoa business. She sells to the village community and relatives 3 days per week. She has had 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be $125 USD.  SPBD loans are Fesuiai’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use part of her loan to assist her with her children's school needs,and for buying new tools for her plantation.

loans.use: To purchase new tools for her plantation

loans.name: Monika

texts.en: Monika Ale, 33, is married with 5 children.  She has many year(s) of experience in the tomatoes, cabbages, cucumbers and long beans. business. She sells to the villagers/public 3 days per week. She has 4 previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~83 USD).  SPBD loans are Monika’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of her loan will help her to improve her vegetable farm and the other part is for her home repairs.

loans.use: back sprayer, vegetable seeds, wheel barrow, barbed wire, calvanize iron, cements,nails and fares.

loans.name: Hul

texts.en:
Since 2003, Hul S. has worked as a vendor selling noodles in a busy market. In one day, she can earn $25. Her husband is a farmer. He owns a plot of farmland and grows vegetables and rice. This couple has five children: four are students, and one daughter now is a hairdresser.

To supplement the household's income, her daughter plans to open a beauty salon. The extra income that will come from the salon will finance the other children’s education. To set up the shop, Mrs. Hul and her husband have agreed to request a loan from Kiva. (Mrs. Hul is pictured.)

loans.use: To set up a beauty salon shop

loans.name: Luafitu

texts.en: Luafitu F., 39, is married with 4 children.  She has many years of experience in the banana plantation business. She sells to the village community and relatives and also at the public market 2 days per week. Luafitu has had 3 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be $145 USD.  SPBD loans are Luafitu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use part of her loan to assist her with her children's school needs,and to buy new farming equipment. Luafitu's husband and children help her a lot with all the hard work on the plantation.

loans.use: The  loan will be using for purchasing equipment like shovels, bushknives,a  weedkiller machine, spades and chemicals.

loans.name: Morn Yang Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Morn Y. is a farmer in Ka Art Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is the group leader of four members.

Mrs. Morn Y. always cultivates her rice twice a year. During the dry season, she grows vegetables. During the rainy season, Mrs. Morn Y. grows rice but she cannot cultivate it well because she has insufficient plow equipment. Consequently, she needs to ask for a loan to buy plow equipment in order to better plow her rice field.

Her husband, Mr. Phon Ev, rents a loudspeaker to people who have a party or wedding ceremony. Mrs. Morn Y. is married and without any children.

loans.use: To buy plow equipment in order to plow her rice field.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. H. Thi Nguyen, 37 years old, joined the Fund in 2003. She is a determined and hard-working woman, and her family has been able to use the past rounds of funding successfully by investing in raising pigs and chicken. Besides the livestock business, she also sells goods at the market. Her husband is also a man who knows how to shoulder his share of the work, and he works as a day laborer and earns about 1,500,000 VND per month. With Mrs. Nguyen’s and her husband’s two jobs, the family always has a continual income stream each month. Since they have been participating in the Fund, the family has always fulfilled their responsibilities as participants. They are very happy that their participation in the Fund has expanded their business and finances so they can take care of their children and send them to school. In this round of funding the couple is requesting 9,000,000 VND to continue farming pigs. The family’s average income is 3,500,000 VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị H., 37 tuổi tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2003, là người phụ nữ năng động chịu khó, qua các vòng vốn vay của Quỹ gia đình chị sử dụng rất hiệu quả, đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, gà. Ngoài việc chăn nuôi chị còn bán hàng tại chợ. Chồng chị cũng là người biết chia sẻ công việc cùng chị, công việc của anh hàng ngày đi làm thuê thu nhâp bình quân 1.500.000đ/ trên tháng. Với việc chị đi chợ và anh đi làm thuê gia đình chị luôn có nguồn thu nhập đều đặn hàng tháng. Từ khi tham gia Quỹ gia đình chị luôn hoàn thành xuất sắc nghĩa vụ của thành viên, anh chị rất hài lòng về việc tham gia vào Quỹ vay vốn phát triển kinh tế, có điều kiện để nuôi con ăn học.Vòng vốn này anh chị xin vay 9.000.000đ tiếp tục chăn nuôi lợn. Thu nhập bình quân gia đình chị 3.500.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: feed pigs

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Not willing to accept perpetual poverty, in 2002 Ms. M. Thi Nguyen and her husband, Thang Van Nguyen, joined the Fund with the goal of borrowing money to expand their business.  In the first year, since they were not yet experienced with the repayment method of weekly payments, they opted to borrow 700,000 VND to buy two breeding pigs.  During the day her husband works to have money for the weekly payment and in a short time the first loan was repaid and at the same time the couple had saved a small amount of money from selling pigs.  Seeing that borrowing loans and repaying on a weekly basis fit well with the needs of the family, in subsequent funding rounds the family boldly borrowed larger amounts to expand the livestock operations.  Under the more favorable conditions of the business operations, the family’s finances have improved day by day, they have been able to afford more everyday conveniences.  The couple has two children, one grown and one still in school.  In this round of funding the family is requesting 9,000,000 VND to continue investing in raising pigs.  Their average revenue from the livestock and other jobs is 3,500,000 VND per month.
Translated from Vietnamese by Chi Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.
Không chịu chấp nhận sự nghèo túng mãi. Năm 2002 chị Nguyễn Thị M. bàn bạc cùng chồng là anh Nguyễn Văn Thặng, tham gia vào Quỹ Tình Thương, với mục đích vay vốn để phát triển kinh tế, năm đầu tiên do chưa quen cách trả tiền theo tuần nên anh chị chỉ vay với mức vốn 700.000đ mua 2 con lợn giống, hàng ngay anh phải đi làm thuê để có tiền trả tuần, chẳng mấy chốc vòng vốn lần 1 đã hoàn thành xong và lúc đó anh chị cũng đã dành giụm được chút vốn nho nhỏ từ việc bán lợn. Nhận thấy việc vay vốn trả theo tuần là phù hợp với điều kiện gia đình, các vòng tiếp theo gia đình anh chị đã mạnh giạn vay vốn cao hơn mở rộng mô hình chăn nuôi, từ những dự án chăn nuôi phù hợp đó kinh tế gia đình chị ngày một thay đổi, mua sắm được nhiệu tiện nghi phục vụ đời sống hàng ngày, anh chị có 2 con, 1 con đã trưởng thành và 1 con đang đi học. Vòng vốn này gia đình xin vay 9.000.000đ tiếp tục đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn.
Thu nhập bình quân từ chăn nuôi và làm thêm: 3.500.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: feed pigs

loans.name: Mataifono

texts.en: Mataifono T., 45, is married with children.  She has many year(s) of experience in the Male and Female outfit business. She sells to the villagers/public 5 days per week. She has 1 previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).
